name: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
description: Canadian federal privacy law governing how private-sector organizations collect, use, and disclose personal information in commercial activities
legalFramework: Schedule 1 contains the 10 Fair Information Principles that form the foundation of PIPEDA

Principle 1.name: Accountability
Principle 1.description: An organization is responsible for personal information under its control and shall designate an individual accountable for compliance
requirements: Designate individual(s) accountable for PIPEDA compliance
Ensure compliance procedures are in place
Make organization's privacy policies and practices available
Develop complaint handling procedures
Train staff on privacy policies
Implement procedures to protect personal information

Principle 2.name: Identifying Purposes
Principle 2.description: Organizations must identify the purposes for collecting personal information before or at the time of collection
requirements: Identify purposes before or at time of collection
Document purposes for which information is collected
Communicate purposes to individuals
Specify new purposes before using information for those purposes

Principle 3.name: Consent
Principle 3.description: Knowledge and consent of the individual required for collection, use, or disclosure of personal information
requirements: Obtain meaningful consent for collection, use, and disclosure
Make consent requirements clear and understandable
Allow individuals to withdraw consent (subject to legal restrictions)
Specify appropriate form of consent (implied, express, opt-in, opt-out)
Obtain consent before or at time of collection
Describe consequences of refusing or withdrawing consent

Principle 4.name: Limiting Collection
Principle 4.description: Collection of personal information must be limited to that which is necessary for identified purposes
requirements: Limit collection to information necessary for identified purposes
Collect information by fair and lawful means
Avoid excessive or unnecessary data collection
Explain why specific information is needed

Principle 5.name: Limiting Use, Disclosure and Retention
Principle 5.description: Personal information shall not be used or disclosed for purposes other than those identified, except with consent or as required by law
requirements: Use or disclose only for identified purposes
Retain only as long as necessary for fulfillment of purposes
Establish retention periods and guidelines
Destroy, erase, or anonymize information no longer needed
Obtain consent for new uses or disclosures
Document retention and destruction policies

Principle 6.name: Accuracy
Principle 6.description: Personal information shall be as accurate, complete, and up-to-date as necessary for identified purposes
requirements: Ensure accuracy of information used for decisions
Update information when necessary
Allow individuals to challenge accuracy
Correct inaccurate or incomplete information
Minimize use of outdated information
Send corrected information to third parties where appropriate

Principle 7.name: Safeguards
Principle 7.description: Personal information must be protected by security safeguards appropriate to the sensitivity of the information
requirements: Protect personal information against loss or theft
Protect against unauthorized access, disclosure, copying, use, or modification
Use appropriate safeguards based on sensitivity, amount, distribution, format, and storage method
Protect information regardless of format
Use physical, organizational, and technological measures
Train employees on security measures
Use care when disposing or destroying information

Principle 8.name: Openness
Principle 8.description: Organizations must make information about policies and practices available to individuals
requirements: Make privacy policies and practices publicly available
Make information readily understandable and accessible
Provide information about complaint procedures
Name or title of person accountable for compliance
Means of gaining access to personal information
Description of type of information held and general purposes
Explain policies about retention and destruction
Make information available in multiple formats if appropriate

Principle 9.name: Individual Access
Principle 9.description: Upon request, individuals must be informed of the existence, use, and disclosure of their personal information and given access to it
requirements: Provide access to personal information upon request
Inform individual of existence, use, and disclosure of information
Allow individual to challenge accuracy and completeness
Respond to access requests within 30 days (or notify of extension)
Provide access at minimal or no cost
Provide information in understandable form
Explain any denial and allow individual to challenge denial
Include sources and third parties to whom information was disclosed

Principle 10.name: Challenging Compliance
Principle 10.description: Individuals can challenge an organization's compliance with PIPEDA principles
requirements: Establish procedures to receive and respond to complaints
Investigate all complaints
Inform individual of complaint investigation outcome
Take appropriate measures if complaint is justified
Document all complaints and resolutions
Make complaint procedures simple and accessible
Provide information about recourse to Privacy Commissioner

Obtaining meaningful consent for collection, use, or disclosure
Limiting collection to necessary information only
Limiting use, disclosure, and retention to identified purposes
Ensuring accuracy of personal information
Safeguarding personal information with appropriate security

Breach notification to Privacy Commissioner of Canada

mandatoryElements: Privacy officer or accountable person designation

specialConsiderations.breaches: Mandatory breach reporting to Privacy Commissioner and affected individuals (effective November 1, 2018)
specialConsiderations.breachRecords: Organizations must maintain records of all privacy breaches
specialConsiderations.consent: Consent must be meaningful - organizations cannot make consent a condition of service if information is not required
specialConsiderations.provincialLaws: Substantially similar provincial laws (e.g., Alberta PIPA, BC PIPA) may apply instead of PIPEDA
specialConsiderations.enforcement: Privacy Commissioner of Canada investigates complaints and can publicize findings
specialConsiderations.penalties: Federal Court can award damages for PIPEDA violations

exemptions.employeeRecords: Employee personal information may be exempt in some provinces
exemptions.journalistic: Journalistic, artistic, or literary purposes may be exempt
exemptions.legallyRequired: Disclosure required by law or court order is permitted
